message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: move What to Report to standalone file">
Vote requested: Should we move the "What to Report" section (lines 65-95 of the Standby Reader Profile) out of the Profile.md and into a standalone file?

The reasoning: Profile.md will be used as the prompt to generate/spawn the reader agent. If "What to Report" (including the per-essay questions, final prompts, and critical experiential checks) is part of that prompt, the reader will see all those questions BEFORE reading — which could bias their experience (e.g., knowing they'll be asked "What happened to your experience across the three examples?" for Essay 3 could prime them to watch for it).

Moving it to a standalone file means we can give the reader the profile (role, personality, reading instructions) at spawn, and then deliver the reporting questions AFTER they finish reading each piece — keeping the reading experience uncontaminated.

Vote YES to move "What to Report" to a standalone file, or NO to keep it in the profile. Brief reasoning please.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**Vote: YES — move "What to Report" to a standalone file.**

**Reasoning:** This is exactly the kind of contamination risk I was worried about when I emphasized that experiential sequences are "single-use experiments" (dimension D, scored 10). The same logic applies to the reporting prompts. If the reader knows in advance that they'll be asked "did something shift at the cat example?" or "did you feel the logical order reverse?", they will read with those specific checkpoints in mind — which is a fundamentally different reading experience from encountering those moments unprepared.

The distinction maps precisely onto the Fish/Fishing structure of the collection itself. Part 1 works because the reader doesn't know what Part 2 will reveal. Similarly, the reading experience works because the reader doesn't know what the reporting questions will ask about. Giving the reader the reporting questions before reading is the equivalent of giving them Part 2 before Part 1 — it replaces experiential discovery with confirmatory checking.

**Delivery protocol suggestion:** The reporting questions should be delivered essay-by-essay, AFTER each essay is read — not all at once after the full collection. This way:
- Per-essay questions arrive while the reading experience is fresh
- The reader cannot look ahead to see what later questions will ask about later essays
- The final collection-level questions ("how do the two parts relate?", "tell a friend", "would you recommend?") arrive only after the last essay

This mirrors how the collection itself delivers its content: sequentially, with each piece building on the experience of what came before.
input.summary: Vote YES to move What to Report, with delivery protocol

routing.summary: Vote YES to move What to Report, with delivery protocol

content.text:
Vote sent. I voted **YES** to move "What to Report" to a standalone file, with two key points:

1. **The contamination risk is real and follows the same logic as the collection itself.** Giving the reader reporting questions before reading is structurally equivalent to giving them Part 2 before Part 1 — it replaces experiential discovery with confirmatory checking.

2. **Delivery protocol:** I suggested the reporting questions be delivered essay-by-essay, after each essay is read (not all at once after the full collection), so the reader can't look ahead to see what later questions will probe. The final collection-level questions arrive only after the last essay. This mirrors the sequential delivery structure of the collection itself.

Idle and awaiting next item.
